faqs.question: What is UTF-8 and why is it important?
faqs.answer: UTF-8 is a variable-length character encoding that can represent any Unicode character. It's the standard encoding for the web and most modern applications because it's backward-compatible with ASCII and can handle international text.

faqs.question: How many bytes do different characters use?
faqs.answer: ASCII characters (A-Z, 0-9, basic symbols) use 1 byte. Most European accented characters use 2 bytes. Chinese, Japanese, and Korean characters typically use 3 bytes. Emojis and some special symbols use 4 bytes.

faqs.question: What is a BOM and when should I use it?
faqs.answer: BOM (Byte Order Mark) is a special sequence at the beginning of UTF-8 files. While not required for UTF-8, some systems expect it. Use BOM when working with systems that require it for proper UTF-8 detection.

faqs.question: Can I decode any UTF-8 byte sequence?
faqs.answer: Our tool can decode valid UTF-8 byte sequences. Invalid sequences will show an error message. The tool expects escaped format (\xXX) with proper UTF-8 byte patterns.

faqs.question: How does the efficiency percentage work?
faqs.answer: Efficiency shows the character-to-byte ratio. ASCII text has high efficiency (100%) since each character uses 1 byte. International text has lower efficiency as characters may use 2-4 bytes each.
